sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_1:
Calculate the determinant of the 3x3 matrix:
$$A=\begin{bmatrix}
2 & 0 & 1 \\
-1 & 3 & 0 \\
4 & -2 & 1 \\
\end{bmatrix}$$
message_2:
To calculate the determinant of a 3x3 matrix, we can use the following formula:

$$\det(A) = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)$$

where the matrix A is given by:

$$A=\begin{bmatrix}
a & b & c \\
d & e & f \\
g & h & i \\
\end{bmatrix}$$

In our case, the matrix A is:

$$A=\begin{bmatrix}
2 & 0 & 1 \\
-1 & 3 & 0 \\
4 & -2 & 1 \\
\end{bmatrix}$$

So, we have:

$$a = 2, b = 0, c = 1, d = -1, e = 3, f = 0, g = 4, h = -2, i = 1$$

Now, we can calculate the determinant:

$$\det(A) = 2(3*1 - 0*(-2)) - 0((-1)*1 - 0*4) + 1((-1)*(-2) - 3*4)$$
$$\det(A) = 2(3) - 0(0) + 1(2 - 12)$$
$$\det(A) = 6 + 0 - 10$$
$$\det(A) = -4$$

So, the determinant of the given matrix A is -4.
